explanation:
1) toxdigitvalue
- Prototype/definition and side‑effect behavior are required so the analyser can determine whether calling toxdigitvalue can change any variables that appear in the loop/selection controlling expressions (for example pct_encoded_len, r, w, buf_size or any global state that those expressions depend on). If toxdigitvalue has side effects that alter variables used in the controlling expressions the expressions might not be invariant; if it is pure (no side effects) that supports the conclusion that the controlling expressions are driven only by the local variables changed in the body.

2) MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
- This compile‑time macro controls which version of the function is present (the first path without the per‑iteration buffer check vs the second path that checks w >= buf_size inside the loop). Whether the macro is defined changes which controlling expressions exist and therefore whether any controlling expression is invariant. The analyser must know the macro definition (defined/undefined) to choose the correct code path for MISRA Rule evaluation.
